docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Prof Ezekiel J Emanuel lauds state-wide medical program in Arkansas that will do away with the fee-for-service model, instead bundling together all of a patient's hospital visits, tests and treatments for a single condition; argues that new method encourages doctors and hospitals to work together to provide patients the highest quality care, while lowering costs. (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Philadelphia MENTION medical innovation, and you might think of the biotech corridor around Boston, or the profusion of companies developing wireless medical technologies in San Diego. But one of the most important hotbeds of new approaches to medicine is ... you didn't guess it: Arkansas.

docs.abstract: An experiment in appointing a doctor or hospital as the "quarterback" to be responsible for an episode of patient care.
docs.snippet: An experiment in appointing a doctor or hospital as the "quarterback" to be responsible for an episode of patient care.

headline.seo: Mayor’s Soda Plan Backed by Weight-Loss Industry
headline.print_headline: Weight-Loss Leaders Back Bloomberg Soda Plan
headline.main: Weight-Loss Leaders Back Bloomberg Soda Plan

docs.abstract: Several well-known weight-loss specialists voice their support for New York City Mayor Michael R Bloomberg’s proposal to restrict sales of large-size sugary drinks; during a news conference, many endorsers are careful to frame the proposal not as a restriction on choices but as a way to nudge New Yorkers toward controlling their portion sizes--a tenet of many weight-loss programs.
docs.lead_paragraph: Several well-known weight-loss specialists announced their support for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposal to restrict sales of big sugary drinks.
docs.snippet: Several well-known weight-loss specialists announced their support for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposal to restrict sales of big sugary drinks.

headline.seo: Calories in Some N.Y.C. School Lunches Were Below Federal Requirements
headline.print_headline: Lunch Trays Got Too Lean In City Fight Against Fat
headline.main: Lunch Trays Got Too Lean in City’s Fight Against Fat

docs.abstract: New York City officials acknowledge that some school cafeterias went too far in cutting fat, ending up serving children meals with fewer calories than are required by the US Agriculture Dept; Education Dept is busy fine-tuning menus to meet federal nutritional standards for the current school year.
docs.lead_paragraph: New federal guidelines have reduced the food minimums for this school year, but some meals for students still require more calories than New York City schools have been providing.
docs.snippet: New federal guidelines have reduced the food minimums for this school year, but some meals for students still require more calories than New York City schools have been providing.

headline.seo: Michelle Obama’s Role in President’s Re-Election Bid
headline.print_headline: First Lady Strives for Caring Image Above Partisan Fray
headline.main: First Lady Strives for Caring Image Above Partisan Fray

docs.abstract: Michelle Obama’s enthusiastic embraces have become a minor phenomenon, with people lining up for hugs at events; signature gesture is a useful metaphor for how Obama approaches the roles of first lady and campaign surrogate, an approach that will be on display when she addresses the Democratic National Convention.
docs.lead_paragraph: Michelle Obama’s enthusiastic embraces have become a minor phenomenon, with people lining up for hugs at events. Her signature gesture is warm and striking.
docs.snippet: Michelle Obama’s enthusiastic embraces have become a minor phenomenon, with people lining up for hugs at events. Her signature gesture is warm and striking.

headline.main: Personal Health: Too Young to Have a Stroke? Think Again

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column warns that stroke poses a very real risk to some young people; notes that up to 15 percent of strokes affect people no older than 45, and that many of those cases go misdiagnosed, increasing the chance of lifelong impairment. Drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Six years ago, Todd McGee was a lean, athletic 34-year-old working in construction and living with his wife and toddler daughter on Martha's Vineyard, where he spent summer weekends surfing. A stroke changed his life forever. Today, with one arm useless and difficulty speaking, Mr. McGee, now 40, cannot work. He devotes most of his time to keeping as healthy as possible. Though he is able to drive and care for his daughter, now 7, everything takes longer, and he has trouble concentrating even on routine activities that others take in stride, like grocery shopping.

headline.print_headline: Personal Health: Too Young to Have a Stroke? Think Again
headline.main: Too Young to Have a Stroke? Think Again

docs.abstract: Up to 15 percent of strokes affect people no older than 45 - and the sooner the correct diagnosis is made, the less likely the result will be lifelong impairment.
docs.snippet: Up to 15 percent of strokes affect people no older than 45 - and the sooner the correct diagnosis is made, the less likely the result will be lifelong impairment.
